) Occupant Emergency Planning (OEP) is an essential physical security program element. It describes responsibilities, contact information, and procedures to follow in case of an emergency. Properly developed plans can minimize emergency event impacts and work disruption. (

) Purpose: This IRM section provides OEP preparation and maintenance guide- lines and requirements for responding to an emergency at an IRS occupied facility. An effective OEP provides occupants with guidance to protect them- selves and other personnel in case of an emergency. Personnel safety is the primary OEP focus while also supporting the protection of IRS assets (e.g., facility, property, equipment, and taxpayer information). (
) Audience: The primary audience is all IRS employees (including contractors with staff-like access) involved in OEP planning and execution. (
) Policy Owner: Chief, Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS). (
) Program Owner: Associate Director (AD), Security. (
) Primary Stakeholders: IRS employees and contractors. (

) Program Goals: The OEP program goal is to provide guidance to all IRS facility occupants to protect themselves and IRS assets during an emergency. The facility OEP is an emergency protocol reference. Employees must know and follow their facility OEP procedures, and participate in scheduled training, testing, and exercises that replicate real-world scenarios to sufficiently prepare for various emergencies. ) IRS Managers must:

a. Review OEP, evacuation, and Shelter-in-Place (SIP) procedures with their employees. b. Ensure sufficient OEP Floor Team (OEPFT) coverage and consider employees telework schedules when assigning OEPFT members. (

) All employees are responsible for: a. Familiarizing themselves with their facility OEP. b. Following instructions during an emergency. c. Participating in drills and exercises. d. Advising their manager of their personal status after any drill or incident for accountability purposes. (

) Program Reports: The FMSS Security office generates reports through the designated security database to assess OEP program core deliverable tions, status, and emergency preparedness level of all IRS employees. (
) Program Effectiveness: To safeguard OEP effectiveness and efficiency, achieve program objectives: a. FMSS Operations:
Develops IRS facility OEP and reviews each facility OEP annually.
Updates OEP emergency contact personnel or responsibilities changes including physical layout of the facility, facility processes or hazards, codes and regulations.
Ensures that the most up to date OEP is available on the OEP repository.
Manages and conducts recurring Emergency Evacuation Drills (EED), and SIP exercises, at a minimum, annually.
Each FMSS SSC reviews EED and SIP checklists to identify and implement best practices and lessons learned. b. FMSS Security:
Maintains policy guidance in compliance with all applicable laws, regula- tions, and ISC standards.
Provides oversight of timely completion of annually required OEP.
Conducts quality reviews of OEP and EED/SIP checklists. (

) Each office or facility occupied by IRS personnel must have an OEP. a. The Occupant Emergency Plan Team (OEPT) develops a facility OEP. This team can consist of a Building Management representative, Federal Protective Service (FPS) personnel, local FMSS Physical Security staff, technical experts, and local authorities. b. The OEPT coordinates with various federal, state, and local agencies and departments that aid during emergencies. Networking with local emergency organizations can increase awareness of local conditions requiring special planning, such as ﬂood, earthquake, and local severe weather hazards. c. OEP planning involves all occupant agencies and non-federal tenants. Non-federal building or facility businesses must be invited to participate. business occupants choose not to participate, the plan can be developed without their input. d. Specify the notiﬁcation process to building management and tenants in the event of an emergency, or potential hazard, such as a ﬁre, water leak, discovery of an explosive device, hazardous material, etc. e. At multi-tenant facilities with an established Facility Security Committee (FSC), FSC members should provide the subject matter expertise to staff the OEPFT and oversee OEP development. f. When IRS acquires new facilities, an interim OEP should be developed the Physical Security Specialist (PSS) and be made available to the ap- propriate business unit employees prior to occupancy, covering at a minimum, emergency evacuation routes and rally points, SIP locations, and emergency phone numbers (i.e., Federal Protective Service (FPS), Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA), FMSS Security Office, other local security on premises). A detailed OEP will be developed no later than
days after occupancy.

) The OEO is a cadre of people responsible for implementing the OEP. The OEO coordinates all facility emergency procedures. The overall OEO structure is designed to be ﬂexible to meet the needs of the individual facility. The OEP must identify and provide the contact information for each OEO and OEPFT member. a. Designated Official (DO) - The DO supervises the OEP staffing and training. The DO has overall responsibility for managing emergencies during normal duty hours, approves OEP activation, coordinates with all tenants during the incident, and oversees OEP development. At facilities where IRS is the primary federal agency, the highest- ranking IRS official at the site, typically the Senior Commissioner’s Representative (SCR) or their designee, serves as the DO. b. Command Center Team - The Command Center Team manages all emergency communication and directs emergency operations. All key OEO members report to the Incident Commander (IC). The Commission- er’s Representative (CR) is the on- site contact for the SCR and acts as the OEP Incident Commander in the SCR’s absence. c. Occupant Emergency Coordinator (OEC) - The DO or designee appoints the OEC. The OEC assists and acts for the DO and serves as liaison with OEO members. The OEC coordinates OEP procedures with other tenants, records emergency procedures used, and provides other administrative services as needed, including soliciting OEPFT members and reviewing Emergency Evacuation and SIP checklists. d. Occupant Emergency Plan Floor Team (OEPFT) - Depending on the facility’s size, structure, and function, the OEO also includes an OEPFT. The OEPFT consists of volunteer tenant employees with designated as- signments. The OEPFT plays a key response role in emergency events. The teams may be called upon to direct evacuations, communicate infor- mation, secure areas, and assist with SIP. The OEP templates outline roles that can be included depending on the facility layout, for example, ﬂoor captains and stairwell monitors. (

) Individuals requiring special assistance during emergencies, including those with temporary or permanent mobility impairments, medical concerns, or hearing or vision impairment must be considered and adequately addressed all aspects of the OEP development, implementation, practical application, and review. a. Individuals requiring assistance must self-identify with their manager of record to be included in the OEP planning. This information is only provided to those with a need-to-know basis. b. Upon request, the manager of record assigns a special assistance monitor (buddy) to assist the individual during evacuations or SIP. Managers should consider assigning a back-up buddy to provide assis- tance if the primary is out of the office (i.e. Alternate Work Schedule (AWS), telework, travel, or leave). c. The manager of record develops notiﬁcation and communication proce- dures and acquires and tests any special equipment needed during an emergency. d. The OEP must include evacuation and SIP procedures for individuals requiring assistance. The procedures should be equally effective as those for other occupants of the facility.

) A pyramid or cascade call system effectively alerts an emergency without wasting communications resources. The DO or responsible designee initiates the emergency action calls by calling one set of individuals who subsequently calls another set of individuals. The number of calls each individual makes varies with organization size. The OEP Planning Team establishes procedures to review contact information accuracy and test the call system. (

) The decision to evacuate depends on the type of threat, its circumstances, where the danger is or suspected to be. The evacuation procedures must provide the fastest evacuation route(s) for all occupants and specify alternate routes in the event the primary route is inaccessible. The primary goal is moving individuals from the danger area as safely and rapidly as possible. (

) In some emergency situations, a full evacuation may not be advisable or practical. Often, a partial evacuation is sufficient, e.g., an emergency situation is localized on one ﬂoor or area. A full evacuation may be required if an incident escalates and threatens occupants in other parts of the facility. partial evacuations, OEPFT members must take care not to move individuals from areas deemed safe through hazardous areas. ) The OEP must specify the occupant notiﬁcation method. Available evacuation communications options vary depending on the type of emergency, the layout, alarm system, and communications systems available. The general facility alarm is typically used for a full evacuation. (
) Evacuation may be advisable prior to a severe weather condition. Depending on the facility, a method of notiﬁcation other than the general alarm may be required. (
) OEPFT members must know the various evacuation signals to promptly and notify facility occupants. Procedures (
) Employees must follow evacuation signals, OEPFT, local FMSS Physical Security staff, and emergency responders’ directions. (

) OEPFT members prevent individuals from re-entering the evacuated building/ area(s) until determined safe and an “all clear” is announced. (

) SIP is appropriate when conditions outside are unsafe and a higher degree protection is available inside. During such events, OEO/OEPFT members, authorities, or emergency responders may instruct occupants to remain at desks or move to pre-designated SIP areas. (

) SIP locations should be identiﬁed in advance with a yellow SIP decal and documented in the OEP. Interior rooms away from outside walls and minimal windows and doors are highly recommended. Select SIP locations based on features that are less vulnerable to outside airborne contaminant releases and provide sufficient space based on occupancy. (
) Unless the speciﬁc threat dictates otherwise, SIP is a short-term measure meant to accommodate a situation for only a few hours. (
) Managers should encourage employees to maintain personal emergency items such as: a. Water b. Medical prescriptions c. Non-perishable food items (

) SIP may be initiated in the following situations: a. Biological or chemical event b. Civil disturbance c. Fire or explosion (outside) d. Natural disaster e. Inclement weather f. Criminal activity or threat in close proximity (

) The DO coordinates with federal or local emergency response officials to provide guidance and direction to an event response. The DO activates the SIP plan and determines the level and the duration. The DO communicates with the OEC, who communicates instructions to the OEO/OEPFT. (

) During a SIP emergency, OEO/OEPFT members must: a. Secure entrances and exits. b. Direct tenants to designated SIP rooms or locations. c. Move occupants away from windows and building entrances/exits. d. Use established notiﬁcation procedures to contact occupants at off-site locations to notify them of the incident and facility closure, until federal local responders give an all-clear. ) A lockdown protects occupants from an active or imminent threat when evacu- ating is not safe, e.g., active shooter. (
) A lockdown is designed to prevent an imminent threat; something that is happening now or will happen very soon. (
) During a lockdown, no one is allowed to enter or exit the facility. (
) Once a lockdown is declared, OEPFT personnel instructs occupants to move out of all open areas such as hallways and stairwells. Occupants must follow emergency personnel directions. (
) Severe weather or other adverse conditions may require office closure and employee notiﬁcation. The IRS Emergency Information Hotline (
) is the primary source of information. Note: For additional guidance on office closings, see IRM

) An active shooter is an individual or individuals actively engaged in harming attempting to harm people in a populated area. An active threat is an incident with a perpetrator posing a risk or immediate threat to life safety. (
) AS/AT plans describe how occupants can most effectively respond to an active shooter situation to minimize the loss of life and provide training on these practices. (

) The DO, facility managers, physical security staff, emergency management personnel, employees, and federal, state, and local law enforcement coordi- nate to develop procedures to increase response effectiveness and limit casualties. (

) An effective AS/AT response plan includes: a. Guidance for occupants to identify individuals who may be on a trajectory to commit a violent act. b. Guidance for neutralizing the threat and achieving life safety objectives. (
) Employees are encouraged to participate in AS/AT awareness training, under- stand the federally endorsed “RUN, HIDE, FIGHT” options and the importance of having a personal plan.

) HAZMAT is any substance or material that, when released in sufficient quanti- ties, poses a risk to health, safety, and property. HAZMAT includes chemical, radiological, or biological substances and materials such as water treatment chemicals, detergents, cleaning supplies, explosives, radioactive materials, ﬂammable liquids or solids, poisons, oxidizers, toxins, and corrosive materials. ) IRS has procedures for a child missing within or from an IRS facility, in accor- dance with the Code Adam Act of
. a. Code Adam is activated when a child is missing within an IRS facility. b. Code Amber is initiated when a child is missing from an IRS facility. (
) Once a child is determined missing “within” an IRS facility, an Adam alert will be initiated in accordance with General Services Administration (GSA) local procedures. (
) Once a child is determined missing “from” an IRS facility, an Amber alert will be initiated. (
) For additional guidance, see the Code Adam and Amber Alert Program - IRS Managers Guide and IRM
